content:
Good clash, but the test cases aren't hard enough to prepare clashers for Validator 5.

I got this in Shortest mode and was tempted to save one character by just doing 9 repetitions of the bubble sort step and assuming it would be sorted by then, which worked for 100% of tests, but it fails for Validator 5. Doing 99 repetitions works and just costs 1 extra character, but it's good to have tests and validators of similar complexity. I recommend adding at least one test with around 20 books.

Good difficulty level for a clash: you have to understand Kendall tau distance, but you don't have to write a whole sort function.

As others have said, you need to include cases that test whether a program works all the way up to the specified constraints. Someone with a very slow program could pass all the tests, submit their code, and then fail the last validator which is significantly bigger than all the visible tests.

Name your tests (for example, "only one book out of place"). This lets programmers see which conditions their code is failing. And make sure the validators test the same things as the test cases.
Ideally should also add a test case closer to the 50 as the max N range.

I don't know if this is what this comment section is about but I've coded it and the tests in ide are fine. I don't like your solution of the problem tho, you're unnecessarly increasing the complexity by calculating the sorted(array) each time (if you want to do this like this you could remeber the value of sorted array after first calculation, it won't change). Maybe it would be cool to increase N and catch someone off guard with it if someone makes the same mistake. I would for sure aprreciate it but again I'm new (clashing for a week now).

I haven't tried solving it yet but here are a few things I saw:
- Make a large test case :P N should also have an upper limit in the constraints
- Include a constraint for the number of minutes for each book
- I could see myself missing the fact that spaces should be ignored when sorting alphabetically, since it's only mentioned briefly in the constraints. But looking at the test cases, it also doesn't seem to be checked, which makes it odd that this requirement exists :/

Assuming there are no duplicates, this is a good contribution!

Okay, I will work on a larger test case later.

About ignoring spaces: The reason that I thought spaces should be ignored is that it may cause some ambiguity as to what the 'alphabetical value'  of a space is, i.e which comes first: "foo" or "fo o". What are your thoughts about this?
currently the biggest sample test is size 5 and validator tests goes up to size 7 and 20, which is problematic.
why is that problematic? The constraints specify the sizes

Usually I go by ASCII value - since spaces have a lower ascii value than lowercase characters, spaces come first.

I think ignoring spaces when sorting is okay, as long as the problem statement makes it much clearer and there are some test cases that make it relevant.

Try a test case like "the medicine" versus "themed ice cube" for this :)
I just tried it, and all the current test cases actually work either way. Should I specify that spaces can optionally ignored, or should I just not say anything about spaces?
You can either make it matter by having some test cases that require it, or not say anything about spaces. :)
Ok. I fixed the things you mentioned. Anything else I should change?

Looks like there are two "Test 7"s and "Test 8"s

Also if the validator is big, the corresponding sample test should also be big ;)

Everything else looks good!

the test cases should be renamed; since only the tests are visible (validators are not, and should check the same thing as the validators with similar but different values to prevent hardcoding while asserting the same behaviour is met) users will only see "Test 1", "Test 3", "Test 5" etc which is weird.

All built-it string comparison functions/operators treat space as lower than letter/digits/punctuations.

"a" < "a a a" < "aa" < "aa a" < "aaa"
